Detailed Description

File containing calculations for front-side and rear-side irradiance of tracked-tilted surfaces.

Function Documentation

◆ solarpos()

void solarpos ( int  year,
int  month,
int  day,
int  hour,
double  minute,
double  lat,
double  lng,
double  tz,
double  sunn[9] 
)

solarpos function calculates the sun position given the local standard time and location.

This function is based on a paper by Michalsky published in Solar Energy Vol. 40, No. 3, pp. 227-235, 1988. It calculates solar position for the time and location passed to the function based on the Astronomical Almanac's Algorithm for the period 1950-2050. For data averaged over an interval, the appropriate time passed is the midpoint of the interval. (Example: For hourly data averaged from 10 to 11, the time passed to the function should be 10 hours and 30 minutes). The exception is when the time interval includes a sunrise or sunset. For these intervals, the appropriate time should be the midpoint of the portion of the interval when the sun is above the horizon. (Example: For hourly data averaged from 7 to 8 with a sunrise time of 7:30, the time passed to the function should be 7 hours and and 45 minutes).

Parameters
[in]year(e.g. 1986)
[in]month(1-12)
[in]dayday of month
[in]hourhour of day local standard time (1-24)
[in]minuteminutes pas the hour, local standard time (1-24)
[in]latlatitude in degrees, north positive
[in]lnglongitude in degrees, east positive
[in]tztime zone, west longitudes negative
[out]sunnarray of elements to return sun parameters to calling function
[out]sunn[0]sun azimuth in radians, measured east from north, 0 to 2*pi
[out]sunn[1]sun zenith in radians, 0 to pi
[out]sunn[2]sun elevation in radians, -pi/2 to pi/2
[out]sunn[3]sun declination in radians
[out]sunn[4]sunrise in local standard time (hrs), not corrected for refraction
[out]sunn[5]sunset in local standard time (hrs), not corrected for refraction
[out]sunn[6]eccentricity correction factor
[out]sunn[7]true solar time (hrs)
[out]sunn[8]extraterrestrial solar irradiance on horizontal at particular time (W/m2)

◆ incidence()

void incidence ( int  mode,
double  tilt,
double  sazm,
double  rlim,
double  zen,
double  azm,
bool  en_backtrack,
double  gcr,
double  angle[5] 
)

incidence function calculates the incident angle of direct beam radiation to a surface.

The calculation is done for a given sun position, latitude, and surface orientation. The modes available are fixed tilt, 1-axis tracking, and 2-axis tracking.

Parameters
[in]mode0 for fixed-tilt, 1 for 1-axis tracking, 2 for 2-axis tracking, 3 for azimuth-axis tracking, 4 for timeseries tilt tracking (in "set surface" function, this is set as mode 0)
[in]tilttilt angle of surface from horizontal in degrees (mode 0), or tilt angle of tracker axis from horizontal in degrees (mode 1), MUST BE FROM 0 to 90 degrees.
[in]sazmsurface azimuth in degrees of collector (mode 0), or surface azimuth of tracker axis (mode 1) with axis azimuth directed from raised to lowered end of axis if axis tilted.
[in]rlimplus or minus rotation in degrees permitted by physical constraints of tracker, range is 0 to 180 degrees.
[in]zensun zenith in radians, MUST BE LESS THAN PI/2
[in]azmsun azimuth in radians, measured east from north
[in]en_backtrackenable backtracking, using Ground coverage ratio ( below )
[in]gcrground coverage ratio ( used for backtracking )
[out]anglearray of elements to return angles to calling function
[out]angle[0]incident angle in radians
[out]angle[1]tilt angle of surface from horizontal in radians
[out]angle[2]surface azimuth in radians, measured east from north
[out]angle[3]tracking axis rotation angle in radians, measured from surface normal of unrotating axis (only for 1 axis trackers)
[out]angle[4]backtracking difference (rot - ideal_rot) will be zero except in case of backtracking for 1 axis tracking

◆ perez()

void perez ( double  hextra,
double  dn,
double  df,
double  alb,
double  inc,
double  tilt,
double  zen,
double  poa[3],
double  diffc[3] 
)

Perez function for calculating values of diffuse + direct solar radiation + ground reflected radiation for a tilted surface and returns the total plane-of-array irradiance(poa), see also isotropic(), hdkr().

Function does not check all input for valid entries; consequently, this should be done before calling the function. (Reference: Perez et al, Solar Energy Vol. 44, No.5, pp.271-289,1990.)

Parameters
[in]hextraextraterrestrial irradiance on horizontal surface (W/m2) (unused in perez model)
[in]dndirect normal radiation (W/m2)
[in]dfdiffuse horizontal radiation (W/m2)
[in]albsurface albedo (decimal fraction)
[in]incincident angle of direct beam radiation to surface in radians
[in]tiltsurface tilt angle from horizontal in radians
[in]zensun zenith angle in radians
[out]poacalculated plane-of-array irradiances (W/m2)
[out]poa[0]incident beam
[out]poa[1]incident sky diffuse
[out]poa[2]incident ground diffuse
[out]diffcdiffuse components, if an array is provided
[out]diffc[0]isotropic diffuse
[out]diffc[1]circumsolar diffuse
[out]diffc[2]horizon brightening

◆ poaDecomp()

int poaDecomp ( double  wfPOA,
double  angle[],
double  sun[],
double  alb,
poaDecompReq *  pA,
double &  dn,
double &  df,
double &  gh,
double  poa[3],
double  diffc[3] 
)

poaDecomp is a function to decompose input plane-of-array irradiance into direct normal, diffuse horizontal, and global horizontal.

Parameters
[in]weatherFilePOAPlane of array irradiance measured from weatherfile (W/m2)
[in]angle[]surface angles calculated from incidence()
[in]sunsun position angles calculated from solarpos()
[in]albalbedo (0-1)
[out]pAstructure containing data required for the decomposition
[out]dnDirect Normal Irradiance (W/m2)
[out]dfDiffuse Horizontal Irradiance (W/m2)
[out]ghGlobal Horizontal Irradiance (W/m2)
[out]poacalculated plane-of-array irradiances (beam, sky diffuse, ground diffuse) (W/m2)
[out]diffcdiffuse components (isotropic, circumsolar, horizon) (W/m2)

◆ ModifiedDISC() [1/2]

double ModifiedDISC ( const double  g[3],
const double  z[3],
double  td,
double  alt,
int  doy,
double &  dn 
)

ModifiedDISC calculates direct normal (beam) radiation from global horizontal radiation.

This function uses a disc beam model to calculate the beam irradiance returned. The argument g is an array of 3 values. The values are the global irradiance of the previous reading, the current reading ,and the next reading in that order. The argument z uses the same format, except the values are the respective solar zenith angles. If any of the g or z values are not available or the previous or next readings did not occur within 1.5 hours of the current reading then the appropriate value or values should be replaced with a -999.0. If the argument td is missing then the value -999.0 should be used in place of the missing argument. The current global irradiance (g[1]) must have a value. If the dew point temperature (td) is missing then td is not used to find an index into the correction matrix (cm), instead a special column in the matrix is used. If the previous global irradiance (g[0]) or solar zenith angle (z[0]) and the next global irradiance (g[2]) or solar zenith angle (z[2]) are missing then delta kt' (dkt1) is not used to find an index into the correction matrix (cm), instead a special column in the matrix is used.

Parameters
[in]g[3]global irradiance array (watts / sq. meter)
[in]z[3]solar zenith angle array (radians)
[in]tddew point temperature (degrees c)
[in]doyjulian day of year
[in]altaltitude of site (meters)
[out]dnbeam irradiance (W/m2)

◆ ModifiedDISC() [2/2]

void ModifiedDISC ( const double  kt[3],
const double  kt1[3],
const double  g[3],
const double  z[3],
double  td,
double  alt,
int  doy,
double &  dn 
)

ModifiedDISC calculates direct normal (beam) radiation from global horizontal radiation.

This is a modification to the orininally provided Modified-DISC model which takes as input the four bin variables and GHI and returns the resulting DNI

Parameters
[in]kt[3]incidence angle modifiers for direct, diffuse, global
[in]kt1[3]kt prime
[in]g[3]global irradiance array (watts / sq. meter)
[in]z[3]solar zenith angle array (radians)
[in]tddew point temperature (degrees c)
[in]altaltitude of site (meters)
[in]doyjulian day of year
[out]dnbeam irradiance (watts / sq. meter) through call-by-reference

shadeFraction1x calculates if the system is shaded based on the sun position and surface position

Parameters
[in]solazisun azimuth in radians, measured east from north, 0 to 2*pi
[in]solzensun zenith in radians, 0 to pi
[in]tiltsurface tilt angle from horizontal in radians
[in]azimuthsurface azimuth in degrees of collector
[in]gcrgrount coverage ratio of system
[in]rotationtracking axis rotation angle in degrees
Returns
fraction shaded (0-1) if system is shaded (0 for unshaded)

backtrack finds the optimum angle to use to reduce self-shading on the front-side of modules using backtracking

Parameters

[in]rotlimplus or minus rotation in degrees permitted by physical constraints of tracker, range is 0 to 180 degrees.
[in]gcrgrount coverage ratio of system
[in]rotationtracking axis rotation angle in degrees
Returns
updated rotation angle in degrees after backtracking
